description: From Middle English demuren, from Anglo-Norman demorer (French demeurer), from Vulgar Latin demorō, Latin demoror (“to tarry”), from de- + moror (“to delay”).
See alternative etymology in the Anglo-Norman ancestor.

entries.meaning: An act of hesitation as to proceeding; a scruple; also, a suspension of action or decision; a pause, a stop.
examples: Most geologists today would accept such evidence without demur, but it was still ‘fringe’ science when du Toit was publishing.

verbs.description: demur (third-person singular simple present demurs, present participle demurring, simple past and past participle demurred)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To linger; to stay; to tarry
(intransitive) To delay; to pause; to suspend proceedings or judgment in view of a doubt or difficulty; to hesitate; to put off the determination or conclusion of an affair.
examples: Vpon this rubbe the English Embassadors thought fit to demurre

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To scruple or object; to take exception; to oppose; to balk
examples: The personnel demurred at the management's new scheme.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To suspend judgment concerning; to doubt of or hesitate about
(transitive, obsolete) To cause delay to; to put off
